stream_context.summary: Kaze shares a major late-stage performance optimization (coin rendering) and begins active development of Course 11’s “abandoned power plant” section. He prototypes and commits to a new paired “weight/scale platform” mechanic, outlines the full room-by-room platforming plan (weight platforms, treadmills, collapsing grates, slide with electric hazards), discusses art direction/texture noise, and touches on team dependencies (Biobak feedback, a delayed paid rework by Mata, upcoming Yoshi Milkman SFX). Personal context includes moving into a new house/basement setup and ending early due to neck pain.
stream_context.significance_reason: Introduces a rare, large (10–15%) performance gain via a concrete rendering change; locks in a new core platform mechanic for Course 11 and lays out the complete gameplay beat map for the power plant section, while also revealing production constraints (full-time job, move, contractor delay).

findings.summary: Kaze reports a major late-stage performance improvement (~10–15%) by changing coin rendering: coins are no longer billboards but rectangles drawn in screen space as sprites, reducing render cost (CMD) and improving FPS in Bunny Brushworks.
findings.quote: This is done by making the coins— instead of having them be billboards, they are now rectangles in screen space… Every coin here is a sprite.

findings.summary: He considers this optimization unusually large for the project’s current stage and frames future major gains as likely tied to eventually implementing F3DEX3.
findings.quote: At this stage, that is crazy… I don't think we will ever see another performance improvement this big. Until we implement F3DEX3.

findings.summary: Course 11 (power plant) is positioned to be around “vanilla Mario 64” difficulty, but Kaze notes RTYI’s improved controls can make challenges look harder than they feel.
findings.quote: About vanilla Mario 64. Although… the controls in this work a lot better. So a lot of stuff can be looking more difficult, while actually being easier.

findings.summary: Kaze begins building the power plant with a clear five-section plan and sketches for two rooms, aiming for an “abandoned, messed-up” vibe; he searches for real power plant/factory references while avoiding overly grainy/noisy texture styles.
findings.quote: We're in an abandoned power plant. Everything's kind of fucked up.

findings.summary: A new platforming mechanic is chosen for the power plant: paired “weight/scale platforms” where standing on one pushes it down and raises its partner. This replaces an earlier idea of simple swinging/dangling movement.
findings.quote: If I move down one, the other one goes up… I think we're going with that idea, yes.

findings.summary: Implementing the weight-platform mechanic reveals engineering constraints: different platform heights and shared motion/return-to-neutral behavior are hard with vertex animation/geolayout sharing, leading Kaze to implement linked behavior logic with shared velocity/friction and a ‘hack’ for better feel.
findings.quote: Sometimes you do need to hack the physics just a little bit to make everything work.

findings.summary: Kaze lays out Course 11’s onboarding flow: Room 1 mood setup + first weight-platform interaction (minimal penalty for failing), Room 2 treadmill introduction with safety net, a slide section timed around electric hazards, then collapsing grates, culminating in a final room combining all mechanics to reach a large star.
He plans environmental lighting to emphasize electricity in the power plant—electric effects/light sources illuminating the scene (vertex lights/fog considered) to sell the industrial mood.
findings.quote: I was gonna have electricity things going through, and the electricity would light up the environment.

findings.summary: Biobak influences multiple decisions: suggests adjusting the ‘soap’ placement in the black boss encounter (move soap to outside grills) and proposes repurposing the dangling platform into the weight/scale mechanic, which Kaze adopts.
findings.quote: I agree with Biobak's idea… I think we're going with that idea, yes.

findings.summary: Kaze shows several recent content updates since last stream: a new star model/texture he prefers over vanilla’s transparent look, improved performance across levels, and an updated hit effect for the ‘black boss.’
findings.quote: I think this is a lot nicer than the transparent star in Vanilla Mario 64.

findings.summary: Kaze pushes back against release-date pressure: he won’t guarantee dates, cites his full-time job, and reiterates the project will release only when finished (with an offhand expectation of “at least mid next year”).
findings.quote: Guys, this releases when it gets done… It's done when it's done.

findings.summary: He reveals a major life change affecting production: he and Zeina just moved into a house (mortgage/bank pressure), and he’s now streaming from a basement setup; he ends early due to neck pain.
findings.quote: We are entirely enslaved to the bank. But we do live in a house now.

findings.summary: Kaze describes a paid contractor situation: Mata (artist) was commissioned to reorganize/upgrade factory visuals, is ~4 months overdue versus a claimed two-week task, and has delivered an early version Kaze thought looked bad; Kaze expresses low confidence but downplays the risk.
findings.quote: He is four months overtime on something that he said would take him two weeks. So my confidence in this is not very high.

findings.summary: He introduces/teases internal codebase improvements: a “tick function instead of a behavior loop” and a new variable-definition approach intended to make memory layout clearer and help detect RAM collisions.
findings.quote: This is legitimately just better… Because now you can actually know when you have RAM collisions.

findings.summary: Kaze articulates strong preferences about game motivation and updates: he dislikes ‘treat hunting’/extrinsic “number go up” rewards, and argues competitive games are harmed by constant balance updates that invalidate learned skill.
findings.quote: I want the game that rewards me with finding cool shit… not extrinsic motivation like, oh, number go up.

biobak.summary: Proposed changing the black boss encounter so soap spawns/flows toward the outside grills/cages, reducing frustration while preserving challenge; Kaze agrees and notes it for later.

Suggested a stronger, more novel platforming idea for Course 11: convert the dangling platform concept into a paired weight/scale mechanism; Kaze adopts it as a unique mechanic not already present in RTYI.
Provides ongoing real-time critique/banter that shapes tone (e.g., ‘message you’re sending’ about minion labor/union jokes) and helps refine comedic in-world signage ideas.

zeina.summary: Kaze frames Zeina as influencing the new streaming/work setup: he’s now in the basement with his CRT/workout gear/Yoshi cabinet, joking that Zeina ‘banished’ him there; she also bought him a mouse (possibly the wrong one).
zeina.quote: Zeina has banished me here. She said I'm not allowed to come up unless it's to grab food.

findings.summary: Acts as a frequent chat interlocutor; Kaze uses Lilaa as a foil for humor and reacts to link filtering/stream feedback (e.g., stream refresh, cursor visibility).
Responsible for a paid factory/power-plant visual rework/reorganization; repeatedly misses deadlines (Kaze cites ~4 months late) and previously delivered a version Kaze strongly disliked.
Creating new custom sound effects for Mario 64/RTYI; Kaze expects them to increase immersion and specifically mentions using appropriate metal/grate sounds for power plant grates.
findings.quote: Yoshi Milkman made so many new sounds for Mario 64… It's going to make the game feel a little more immersive.

findings.summary: Referenced indirectly via Kaze’s mention that future performance gains may come ‘until we implement F3DEX3,’ which is associated with Sauraen’s prior microcode collaboration (no new detail given this stream).

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: Guys, this releases when it gets done… It's done when it's done.
memorable_quotes.context: Pushback against chat pressuring for release dates; encapsulates his boundary-setting and reality of building RTYI alongside a full-time job.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: I want the game that rewards me with finding cool shit… not extrinsic motivation like, oh, number go up.
memorable_quotes.context: Explains his taste in game rewards and exploration, a key lens for how he redesigns Mario 64 into something ‘new but respectful.’

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: Sometimes you do need to hack the physics just a little bit to make everything work.
memorable_quotes.context: Said while tuning the new weight-platform behavior; summarizes pragmatic engineering choices needed on N64-era constraints.

key_stories.title: Late-stage performance breakthrough via coin rendering
key_stories.summary: Kaze reveals a surprising 10–15% performance gain in an already-optimized project by changing how coins are drawn. He demonstrates higher FPS and lower render command cost in Bunny Brushworks, presenting it as one of the last big wins before heavier engine upgrades like F3DEX3.
key_stories.challenge: Achieving meaningful frame-rate gains late in development when most obvious optimizations are already done.
key_stories.process: Identified coin billboards as expensive; replaced them with screen-space rectangle sprites; measured FPS/CMD with and without debugger.
key_stories.outcome: Notable FPS increase and reduced CMD, with many areas now near-consistent 60 FPS; establishes a template for future render-cost reductions.
key_stories.key_quote: At this stage, that is crazy… I don't think we will ever see another performance improvement this big.

key_stories.title: Locking in Course 11’s signature mechanic: weight/scale platforms
key_stories.summary: While prototyping dangling platforms, Kaze hits constraints around animation, shared geolayouts, and varying platform heights. Biobak suggests repurposing the idea into a paired weight-platform system, which Kaze adopts and begins implementing with shared velocity/friction and gameplay-driven ‘feel’ tweaks.
key_stories.challenge: Creating a new platform type that is mechanically fresh, readable, and technically feasible within SM64’s object/geo constraints.
key_stories.process: Evaluates vertex-animation vs object rotation; realizes height/animation conflicts; shifts to linked platform objects; iterates on return-to-neutral behavior and acceleration/friction; adds small physics ‘hacks’ for responsiveness and player agency.
key_stories.outcome: A committed new mechanic for the power plant with an onboarding plan and room sequencing built around it.
key_stories.key_quote: I think we're going with that idea, yes.

key_stories.title: Designing the abandoned power plant as a teach-then-test sequence
key_stories.summary: Kaze outlines the power plant’s rooms as a structured tutorial arc: mood-setting entry, first weight-platform interaction with low penalty, treadmill introduction with a safety fallback, slide timing around electric hazards, then collapsing grates, ending with a final combined challenge and a large star.
key_stories.challenge: Balancing difficulty (vanilla-like) with RTYI’s smoother controls while ensuring mechanics are introduced clearly before being combined.
key_stories.process: Plans five sections/rooms and sketches; places ‘safe failure’ geometry; sequences mechanics (weight platforms → treadmills → slide hazards → collapsing grates → finale); considers lighting/fog/electric illumination for atmosphere.
key_stories.outcome: A concrete, interviewable blueprint for Course 11’s pacing and player learning goals.

key_stories.title: Managing a delayed paid art rework (Mata)
key_stories.summary: Kaze discusses paying Mata to reorganize/upgrade factory visuals because Mata needed money, but the work has slipped months beyond the promised timeline. Kaze expresses skepticism based on an early terrible-looking build, but frames it as a known risk and not catastrophic due to indoor culling and flexible poly budgets.
key_stories.challenge: Keeping production moving when a paid contractor misses deadlines and quality expectations.
key_stories.process: Commissioned the work; reviewed an early version and gave feedback (‘try harder’); decides to ‘hold off’ others’ work until the rework resolves; mentally derisks the delay by accepting fallback options.
key_stories.outcome: Factory visuals remain a dependency with uncertain delivery (claimed June 1), affecting when others should commit to final art/texture work.
key_stories.key_quote: I would say he is saying he's reworking the factory.

key_stories.title: Life move and physical limits shaping production
key_stories.summary: Kaze reveals he’s streaming from a new basement setup after moving into a house, joking about being ‘banished’ by Zeina. Neck pain interrupts the session and prompts ending early, reinforcing the reality that RTYI development must fit around adult life, health, and a full-time job.
key_stories.challenge: Sustaining a long ROM-hack project under real-world time/health constraints.
key_stories.process: Sets up a new workspace; continues development despite discomfort; chooses to stop the stream to rest rather than push through.
key_stories.outcome: Shortened stream; reinforces why release dates are uncertain and why progress can fluctuate.
key_stories.key_quote: My neck pain today makes this kind of uncomfortable. And I think I'm going to end stream here.

open_questions.topic: Coin sprite optimization and broader render strategy
open_questions.context: Kaze replaced coin billboards with screen-space sprite rectangles for a major FPS/CMD gain, and suggests no other optimization this large is likely before F3DEX3.
questions: How did you identify coins as the bottleneck (profiling tools, intuition, CMD breakdown)?
What tradeoffs did you accept (visual differences like spin behavior, depth cues, z-sorting)?
Are there other object classes you plan to convert similarly (particles, pickups, UI-like world objects)?
How do you decide when an object should be true 3D vs screen-space sprite in RTYI?

open_questions.context: Kaze frames future big performance improvements as tied to implementing F3DEX3 but gives no details here.
questions: What features/perf wins do you expect specifically from F3DEX3 in RTYI?
What are the biggest integration risks (compatibility with existing materials, microcode limits, tooling)?
Who is responsible for the integration work and what is the timeline dependency?

open_questions.topic: Course 11 final art direction and lighting system
open_questions.context: Kaze wants an abandoned power plant vibe, dislikes grainy/noisy textures, and considers electricity-driven lighting, fog, and vertex lighting.
questions: What’s the final visual reference set for Course 11 (real plants vs Mario Galaxy/Bowser factory inspirations)?
How will ‘electricity lights the room’ be implemented on N64 (dynamic lights, baked vertex colors, emissive tricks)?
What are the readability rules so industrial clutter doesn’t hide platform edges?
Where do you draw the line on ‘high-poly indoors’ vs performance safety margins?

open_questions.topic: Weight/scale platform mechanic—final rules and exploits
open_questions.context: Kaze prototypes linked platforms with shared velocity/friction and mentions adding small physics hacks for responsiveness and height manipulation; he also notices potential sequence breaks.
questions: What are the exact final rules (acceleration curve, max travel, reset timing, ground-pound effects)?
How do you prevent or embrace sequence breaks/speedrun tech with inertia and ground pounds?
What playtesting will you do to validate ‘normal players can do this’ sizing/difficulty?
Will this mechanic appear outside Course 11 as a recurring language, or stay unique to the power plant?

open_questions.context: Kaze places ‘star three’ in the final room and describes a linear teach-then-combine gauntlet; he also shows a separate ‘black boss’ and mentions soap mechanics.
questions: How do Course 11’s missions differ across stars—do they remix rooms or open new routes?
Where does the black boss fit in Course 11’s mission order (which star/mission)?
How do you keep an indoor multi-room course from feeling too linear compared to classic SM64 courses?

open_questions.context: Kaze says all music is custom and highlights upcoming custom SFX (metal grates, immersion), implying a broader sound redesign.
questions: What is the scope of Yoshi Milkman’s SFX pack (player moves, enemies, environment, UI)?
How do you handle memory/ROM space constraints for higher variety SFX?
How do you direct sound style so it feels ‘Mario 64-like’ but fresh?
How does custom audio support Course 11 specifically (electric hazards, machinery, ambience)?

open_questions.topic: Managing contractors and schedule risk (Mata rework)
open_questions.context: Kaze paid Mata to reorganize/upgrade factory visuals; delivery is months late with quality concerns, affecting whether others should start on final textures.
questions: What was the original contract/scope for Mata—‘reorganize’ vs full re-art?
How do you handle payment, milestones, and accountability on a fan project?
What’s the contingency plan if the June 1 delivery is missed or still unusable?
How do delays change your production ordering (design first vs art first)?

open_questions.topic: Release strategy under a full-time job
open_questions.context: Kaze repeatedly refuses release dates and implies a timeline of at least mid-next-year, citing full-time work and life changes.
questions: What does ‘done’ mean for RTYI (content complete, polish, bug count, performance targets)?
Do you have internal milestones even if you won’t share dates publicly?
How do you prevent burnout while keeping momentum with a demanding day job?
What would make you consider a public demo vs waiting for a full release?

open_questions.topic: Codebase architecture changes (tick function, variable system/RAM collisions)
open_questions.context: Kaze mentions moving to a tick function instead of a behavior loop and a new variable-definition approach that clarifies memory layout and reveals RAM collisions.
questions: What was the previous behavior/loop model and what problems did it cause?
How does the new variable system work in practice (tooling, macros, validation)?
Can you give an example of a RAM collision you found/avoided because of this change?
How do these architectural choices help collaborators contribute safely?

open_questions.topic: Design philosophy: intrinsic rewards and ‘respectful’ remixing
open_questions.context: Kaze rejects extrinsic ‘collect-a-thon treats’ as primary reward and wants discovery of meaningful concepts; this philosophy likely shapes RTYI’s course design and pacing.
questions: How does this philosophy translate into star objectives and level beats in RTYI?
What do you consider ‘cool concepts’ worth rewarding the player with on N64 hardware?
How do you balance nostalgia/respect for SM64 with adding unfamiliar mechanics?
Where do you intentionally deviate from SM64 conventions, and why?
